These 4 TCs are not needed (actually they are incorrect). Users (both OS and ldap) are not locked out after 3 failed attempts, they are locked out after 5 failed attempts.

What are really needed to test is to ensure sudo command doesn't yield 2 consecutive "Sorry, try again" and exit, as following:
localhost:~$ sudo bash
Password: 
Sorry, try again.
Sorry, try again.
sudo: 3 incorrect password attempts

A sudo command should yield only one "Sorry, try again" and allow user to try password again 2 more times, as following:
controller-0:~$ sudo su
Password:
Sorry, try again.
Password:
Sorry, try again.
Password:
sudo: 3 incorrect password attempts
Done

So, I had to look this up.  reading the docs for sudo, pam_tally, and this "not-a-bug" from redhat: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=652596

My understanding is that pam is doing what it is supposed to do: deny another login for 15seconds.  But sudo is trying up to 3 times (the default is passwd_tries=3).

Apparently, sudo gets away with trying again if lock_time is only 3 (?)

Yes, with lock_time = 3, sudo command with a wrong password will yield only one "Sorry, try again", and allow user to retry password, like following:
controller-0:~$ sudo su
Password:
Sorry, try again.
Password:
Thanks Karla, looks good to me

this change will drop the delay after a failed login attempt from 15 seconds down to 3.
It is not clear to me how that was causing multiple login fails for one bad input, but the experts approve so merging.

swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3request..message: is this just translating an internal swift api 503 for a container listing into a 503 s3api response?

Yup -- so the traceback looks like

InternalError: 500 Internal Server Error (unexpected status code 503): 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".../swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3api.py", line 303, in __call__
    resp = self.handle_request(req)
  File ".../swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3api.py", line 341, in handle_request
    res = handler(req)
  File ".../swift/common/middleware/s3api/controllers/base.py", line 60, in wrapped
    return func(self, req)
  File ".../swift/common/middleware/s3api/controllers/base.py", line 71, in check_container
    req.get_container_info(self.app)
  File ".../swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3request.py", line 1483, in get_container_info
    'unexpected status code %d' % info['status'])
InternalError: InternalError: 500 Internal Server Error (unexpected status code 503)

and it's coming because we special-case InternalError responses: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.26.0/swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3api.py#L298-L299

I'm torn about whether that's good or misguided -- but it's been around a while; since 2014 it looks like: https://github.com/openstack-archive/swift3/commit/6448a43ef8e96b8c69d8c256938eb3f52543b75e#diff-869603ff0d5a187be1c30ce54a125fa8481abc88bd016417bf14a216aabe8836R918-R920

Regardless of whether a traceback on all raised InternalErrors is appropriate or not, though, I think it's probably for the best that we keep updating our status-code translations to try to minimize the number of "unexpected status code" errors, if only so the 500s that remain are more actionable and better able to be prioritized.
oic, this is on the BASE S3Request object - so this catches a lot of call sites.
*and* we were already raising an error - so it's just about changing the type of the raised exception - which does something with logs that's helpful

manilaclient/tests/functional/osc/test_s.message:
This test as it is written is destructive. Tests run via multiple threads in parallel; so provisioning, share management requests could be happening on the service you're temporarily disabling. Granted that the test wraps up really fast and re-enables the service, however, we could potentially see spurious test failures because some other operation was attempted within the brief window that the service was disabled. 


One option is to target the "manila-data" service - we're not exercising it in any of the functional tests (we can't really). So instead of using the first service with lines 44-45, look for the service with binary "manila-data"

api-ref/source/versions/index.rst.message:
Everyone seems to find this way of presenting the API history completely confusing (even me, and I'm pretty sure I wrote the original patch).  What might be better is for each release, just say what the current version is and what new functionality it introduced (because that's what people really care about).  To figure this out, you may need to do some digging into the patches incrementing the version.  Here's some info I found when working on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance/+/840409

This tells you when each version was introduced, but not which are current or supported.  Additionally, which is current in each release may depend on config options.  So, for example, some releases have two different CURRENT APIs depending on whether you have multistore enabled or not.  So maybe instead of saying what the current API is for each release, just say what the maximum is and what functionality you get.

  *  requires multistore enabled
  ** requires caching enabled
  2.7     hidden images and multihash  commit: 8e16e41f   Rocky
  2.8*    EXPERIMENTAL multistore      commit: 208935af   Rocky   
  2.9*    EXPERIMENTAL multistore      commit: d9546dce   Train
  2.9**   caching                      commit: 515412b5   Train
          (not sure what this is, ask Erno)
  2.10*   delete-from-store            commit: f267bd6c   Ussuri
  2.11*   multistore (not sure what)   commit: 0e3d2749   Wallaby
  2.12    messages (image import)      commit: af3ce1ad   Wallaby
              GET /v2/images/{image_id}/tasks 
  2.13*   quota usage API              commit: f865b8ca   Yoga
          (not sure why this requires multistore)
  2.14**  cache management             commit: 87eae327   Yoga
  2.15    store info                   commit: a34764ec   Yoga
  2.16**  cache mgmt resp code fix     commit: 55c000e    Yoga (not merged yet)
                                       commit: 11989a1    master

specs/zed/add-capacity-factors-to-get-po.message: I think this line should be removed, it's a placeholder for the blueprint link
This looks incomplete, I think the purpose was to explain each of the factors above (or at least complete the reserved_percentage description).
currently this is already reported as total_capacity_gb?

Just remember, everything in the capabilities is what's being reported by the driver and volume manager at the time the last get_volume_stats() was called.  What's in the capacity factors dictionary is modified from those capabilities values in between the stats call.  They can and will be different depending on when the call to cinder get-pools --detail was called.    They are labeled the same, but the values can be different.   As ad administrator I want to see what the scheduler sees at the time I call get-pools, not what the driver reported last time it was called.  Sometimes I want to see both of those.
actually even the free_capacity_gb can be different in between calls to get_volume_stats() as the scheduler decrements this value when it marks the pool as having consumed a new volume.

yes it's the same value, but this dict is the entire story of all of the capacity factors that that scheduler uses.  I don't want to leave out some simply because they are already in the capabilities.

Given the parameters that are already reported in capabilities[1], some of them are redundant in this new dict. Can we only specify those parameters which are newly added?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/2937ef77028d6ed3e1ff992ad75a62cf96e8ebb1/cinder/interface/volume_driver.py#L68-L150

They look redundant but aren't.  

The capabilities are reported by the driver.
These values are modified in real time by the scheduler to be used for provisioning requests, which can be and are often different than what is reported by the driver, until the next time get_volume_stats() is called.

I would really like this to be pointed out in the spec that the new capacity factors being reported are not the ones currently returned in capabilities and are a reflection of current state of scheduler vs what is being reported by get_volume_stats()

ansible/roles/disable-selinux/tasks/main.message: A reboot is only required if it is enabled or disabled. Going from enforcing to permissive and back again can be applied immediately.
The selinux module provides a reboot_required variable. I updated the role to use it.

ansible/roles/selinux/defaults/main.yml.message: Did we agree to making this false by default? Otherwise a host configure will reboot all hosts previously deployed with selinux disabled.
That's exactly what we agreed. I missed updating this part.

ansible/roles/selinux/tasks/main.yml.message:
According to Ansible docs possible states are: disabled, enforcing, permissive

I think we will need to check the current state to figure out if a reboot is needed.

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/posix/selinux_module.html
The selinux module provides a reboot_required variable. I updated the role to use it and remove the check of selinux_state ('enabled' was not valid anyway).

This isn't quite how I remembered the outcome of our discussion. I thought we had agreed to first run the selinux module with check_mode=true, then fail if necessary before making changes. This would allow the user to either set selinux_do_reboot to true, or change the kayobe state to match the running state.

I suppose the main thing we'd want to avoid is if the user sets selinux_do_reboot to true, but on the second run we don't see reboot_required. Have you tested that case?
Thanks for testing, I think this is fine.
I will need to do some actual testing then. I will push an updated patch once done.

I am not sure we need to use check_mode. Subsequent invocations of the selinux module will still notice that a reboot is needed.

First run:

TASK [selinux : Ensure desired SELinux state] **************************************************************************************************************************************************************
[WARNING]: SELinux state change will take effect next reboot
changed: [seed]

TASK [selinux : Abort SELinux configuration because reboot is disabled] ************************************************************************************************************************************
fatal: [seed]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "SELinux state change requires a reboot, but selinux_do_reboot is false. Please run again with selinux_do_reboot set to true to reboot.\n"}

Second run:

TASK [selinux : Ensure desired SELinux state] **************************************************************************************************************************************************************
[WARNING]: SELinux state change will take effect next reboot
ok: [seed]

TASK [selinux : Abort SELinux configuration because reboot is disabled] ************************************************************************************************************************************
fatal: [seed]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "SELinux state change requires a reboot, but selinux_do_reboot is false. Please run again with selinux_do_reboot set to true to reboot.\n"}

Third run with reboot allowed:

TASK [selinux : Ensure desired SELinux state] **************************************************************************************************************************************************************

def copy_schema_keys(copy_from_module, exclude_schema=[]):
    dir = vars(copy_from_module)
    schema_keys = list(filter(lambda key: not key.startswith('__')
                              and key not in exclude_schema and

def update_module_attribute(copy_from_module, current_module, keys):

    # copy the schema

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Thanks for the review Alexandre!

The whole idea to use the schema version is that we are trying to work as safe as possible. To enable us to enable/disable features. The schema versioning allow us to achieve that. That is why it was put as requirement to this patch. So, we can control/revert any new feature/option that is enabled in the identity federation integration of Keystone.

It is not an issue for this one to depend on that. The issue is that these patches, and specially that proposal got stuck. They could have been merged already.

Thks Rafael for submitting this, we also are interested to have this feature on, as we want to plug keystone a centralized IAM service, that will be aware of project/user/role ownership for wide range of customers. Handling service access via projects_json in this case is much more scalable than constantly updating a static huge mapping entry through keystone api.

I'm globaly fine with this specs, except the few comments related to dependancy with another change 'honor domain', which I think is not necessary here.

Note that we propose an alternative implementation here: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone/+/844098 (still need few work)that do not require mapping schema versioning.

I totally agree that versioning the schema can be handled, and produce a lot of advantage, but I think in this case it is not necessary to put that as a dependency of this particular spec. Indeed, adding a new non breaking field in the API should be transparent for the user, and can only produce a microversion bump like in other Openstack project, or even lately in keystone for v3.14: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/commit/8153a9d5925b0ba60e43329ff6bfb5a4d1a12f97

I just think it is easier for every reviewer to put less dependency between patches, and to take them on their own if possible.

The requirement is on purpose. So, we easily maintain this extensions. The patch that this one depends on is the patch that introduces the schema versioning. It should already have been merged, but it was ignored for a long time. I am trying to reach Keystone folks with core review premission to move on with that patch without success.

P.S. the requirement of schema versioning is not a bad thing. It is a good thing to facilitate further developments. For instance, we already implemented internally extensions of top of this one such as roles "activation_rules", which means, rules inside the roles of projects that define when they should/can be assigned to users according to attributes that come from the IdP and the context of the user accessing the system (e.g. time, source IP, and so on).

Alexandre, 

We also already had a patch open for a very very long time for this spec: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone/+/742235

For two reasons: first,  we need the schema_versioning feature because I would introduce a new schema version with this patch; second, I need Keystone to honor domain definition in the attribute mapping to execute cross-domain assignments.


The other sections you mention, I did not introduce because I did not think that I needed them. Also, about security impacts, I did not see any that was not already there. If you have something in mind, let me know, and then I can incorporate it here.

Sure. Done.

Done

Well, it is pretty much what is said there. I mean, if there is an attribute that comes from the IdP, and if this attribute contains a JSON definition with all of the projects where the user should be assigned to (with respective roles), the current implementation cannot handle that.

What didn't you understand? Then, maybe, I can try to address it.
I'm asking for examples to be written down in the spec.
How is this different from auto-provisioned projects and roles? https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/federation/mapping_combinations.html#auto-provisioning

The auto provision that you mention is static. Even though it is a list, it is a list that is built with a find/replace mechanism with the attributes that come from the IdP, and that are retrieved via the "remote" section. That `projects` option there does not scale if we have users with a single project assignment at the same time that we have users with 5, 10, or more.

In the current implementation, once we define two projects, it will expect two, nothing less, nothing more. Did you understand what I mean?

Please don't use python code snippets in a spec, specs aren't for implementation, they are for design and API changes. Explain the feature by explaining the changes to the JSON API that a user would see in https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3-ext/#mappings
It is only to illustrate the new property that we are adding. I see no harm in adding this here.

I think we don't need to introduce mapping schema version for this change, because it is just extending current schema without breaking existing deployment after upgrade.

In other words, this change must not necessary depends of this specs: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone-specs/+/748042/
In this change ^^ Rafael introduces mapping schema versioning because "honoring domain" may involve a change of behavior in existing deployment. It is not the case here for adding projects_json assertion.

I don't really get the point of willing to disable this option on the fly. Indeed, adding a new possible field in this API (mostly admin related btw) doesn't enforce it anywhere, and operators can still decide to not using it, despite a versioning of the schema. For me, if we want to add more limitation on this field, it should be done through the policy, not a version of the API.

It can be a case of not wanting to handle projects_json field. For instance, if somebody wants to enable/disable this option on the fly. That is the whole idea behind the schema version, and why we first introduced the schema version before any other feature in Keystone.

There is no harm in that initial patch. It only facilitates the handling of new options being created in the attribute mapping schema. It should have been merged a very long time ago.

We are touching the authorization part of a complex system. If there is an issue with the implementation, we should be able to fallback somehow to the previous one. That is why this one was implemented on top of the schema versioning. I know that if one does not use it, in theory, they can set/remove the new attribute that is coming from the IdP. Or, updating the whole attribute mapping. However, that is one point, being able to activate/deactivate a function/option without changing the attribute mapping.

Anyways, the whole history is now mixed. This patch was only created after the schema versioning was introduced (spec and implementation proposed here). Therefore, when we have that, we should always create a new schema version when adding new option in the attribute schema. That is why it was proposed as schema 1.2. The whole situation like this one only appeared because we were not able to move on that patch, even though it was approved and agreed in its content and form. It is not that we were not putting the effort, but it is that nobody was responding to our pings there.
same as before, I think we can remove it.

Thanks John, just wondering if [4] is then ignored as we're using the tripleo.operator here

What this new line in TQE does results in the following happening in 4:

if standalone_container_ceph_updates is true:
extra_vars['tripleo_cephadm_container_ns'] = 'quay.rdoproject.org/tripleomastercentos9'

if standalone_container_ceph_updates is false:
extra_vars['tripleo_cephadm_container_ns'] = container_dict['ceph_namespace']

Where container_dict represents what was in containers-prepare-parameters.yaml

I wrote the above in pseudo code so I could share variables across projects to make the logic more clear.


[4] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_ceph.py#L564-L566

Yes. In more detail, the following happens in order:

A. As per [1], containers-prepare-parameters.yaml has its ceph_namespace updated
B. Then 'openstack overcloud ceph deploy' is called which triggers python-tripleoclient
C. As per [2], python-tripleoclient will parse containers-image-prepare.
D. As per [3], it will then substitute whatever container_namespace was set with push_destination (because containers-prepare-parameters.yaml has push_destination for periodic jobs)
E. As per [4], it will then ignore that substitution and set namespace to parsed_args.container_namespace
F. Then when Ansible is called to bootstrap ceph with extra_vars with the namespace

When standalone_container_ceph_updates is false, --containers-name is not passed so the same thing as above happens but without E.

I don"t see the difference between this test and test_list_groups. The exact same set of groups is returned by the call to list_groups. So if their is a bug in Keystone (like the domain_id being completely ignored) this test won't catch it.

There is a similar test in list_users that was pre-existing. I added this test and did not conditionally enable it to be consistent with the test in list_users.

I left the duplicate code as to not make the tests more abstract than necessary.

Maybe this test could get a `skip.Unless(CONF.identity_feature_enabled.multiple_backends)` decorator? This way only one of the tests will be executed.

Also the common lines of code between `test_list_group_with_domains` and `test_list_groups` could be abstracted into a single private function.

When domain_specific_drivers=True, Keystone list_groups would return the groups for the current token's domain, not the domain we created above. However, if domain_specific_drivers=False, list_groups will return all groups from all domains without any filtering (there are some fringe cases where this may also occur with multiple_backends enabled).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Nova changed their API for a good reason. I agree that we should allow operators to keep their old broken data, but we should not do so by default.
I updated my change following the discussion in today's IRC meeting.

Well the flavor_id is only useful if the flavor hasn't been removed, so it depends on how static the available set of flavors is. Though I admit that in most deployments it likely indeed will not change very often.

I still don't see how changing the default in AA would be different from changing it now, though. I'd still prefer changing now and adding a fat warning in the reno about it. For backports then we can switch this around and use 2.1 as default.

Happy to be overruled by other reviewers though.

In theory I would agree with you, I normally prefer to use defaults. However in practice we have two main issues:

- operators may depend on metrics that were removed, but not realise they become unavailable until after they upgrade. This gives them a chance to adapt. I was thinking we could revert to the default microversion in a future release. The Nova docs say the metrics are "frequently misleading or outright wrong", but I have found them useful.

- the flavor_id label of openstack_nova_server_status is incorrect with microversions 2.47 or above. Before: flavor_id="1", after: flavor_id="<nil>" (issue #220 linked in commit message). This will require adding support in openstack-exporter to display flavor information in a new way. Until this is implemented, using microversion 2.1 provides useful data.

Using the latest microversion mostly removes information. The only actual change is the move from numeric IDs to UUIDs for openstack_nova_agent_state:

-openstack_nova_agent_state{adminState="enabled",disabledReason="",hostname="pierre-aio.novalocal",id="1",service="nova-scheduler",zone="internal"} 1
+openstack_nova_agent_state{adminState="enabled",disabledReason="",hostname="pierre-aio.novalocal",id="063b0a69-e30f-4450-8dfa-6bbf0bc2d0e9",service="nova-scheduler",zone="internal"} 1

Overall I see more downsides to using the latest microversion, especially without a transition period. What do you think?

ansible/roles/prometheus/defaults/main.y.message: it does not work the way you think; in the environment we now have a funny value for this variable - we need to construct the dictionary or filter it out

"omit" emits a magic string that only Ansible knows how to handle for the module params. Other places simply get the very weird string. The reason this works is because it gets the empty string and this causes the env var to go empty.
Alternative approach in which we always set the environment variable. What do you think?

I tried with default(omit, true). It works when first setting the environment variable – it won't define it in the container environment if set to empty string – but it won't unset it if it has been defined.

I think this might be an issue with kolla_docker itself?
Also since the value has a default, this bit would never be used.

pack_wheel.py.message:
Probably better to do something like

 sys.executable, '-m', 'pip', 'wheel', ...

This can do unexpected things when using system packages and both py2 and py3 are installed.
No longer using pip to build the initial wheel.

Drop this; let it warn -- the alternative is to have old versions of pip barf and say things like

 no such option: --use-feature
No longer using pip to build the initial wheel.

This may be too brittle; old versions of pip say something like

    Running setup.py bdist_wheel for pyeclib: started
    Running setup.py bdist_wheel for pyeclib: finished with status 'done'
    Stored in directory: /home/pi/code/pyeclib
  Successfully built pyeclib

...which isn't terribly useful :-/ Might need to get a tempdir, run something like

 pip wheel src_dir -w temp_dir

then sanity check that we only have the one wheel in there. Fortunately, we only *really* care about the filename anyway; no need to discover/calculate size or sha256.
No longer using pip to build the initial wheel.
This feels suspicious (shouldn't it be contingent upon us running this on py35+?) but apparently it works out in practice.

FWIW, this script should still be useful even without all the docker business. After installing patchelf and auditwheel on my raspberry pi, I can run

 python pack_wheel.py .
 python3 pack_wheel.py .

and get myself some manylinux2014 wheels for armv7l, for example. I expect we could get to something similar for OS X and Windows, but that's out of scope for now -- at the very least we'd want to change up the shared-object file extension.

Went ahead and made OS X support in-scope for this change. I don't know that anyone's ever managed to build liberasurecode (much less pyeclib) for Windows -- I tried (somewhat half-heartedly) and didn't get far, anyway.
Might be indicative of a bug, but building pyeclib on OS X still makes a pyeclib_c.abi3.so, not a pyeclib_c.abi3.dylib as I'd originally expected.
libec and isal will be dylibs though!
